description: On March 19, 2020, the Kuwaiti government announced the closure of schools and other educational institutions to be extended to August 4, 2020. They will reopen for five to six weeks to make up for the missed period of the second semester. The next academic year will begin later on December 1, 2020. Educational institutions were already initially closed from March 12 as part of the nation-wide 2 week public holiday.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: Since March 22, 2020, Kuwait has implemented a nationwide curfew which is presently in effect. Those in violation of the curfew order will be imprisoned for up to three years and fined 10,000 KD. Foreign nationals found in violation of the curfew order also risk deportation.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
Since March 22, 2020, Kuwait has implemented a nationwide curfew is in effect from 5:00pm until 4:00am. Those in violation of the curfew order will be imprisoned for up to three years and fined 10,000 KD. Foreign nationals found in violation of the curfew order also risk deportation.
On April 20, 2020, the Kuwait government has decided to extend partial curfew for 16 hours up until May 28 from 4 pm until 8 am.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
Since March 22, 2020, Kuwait has implemented a nationwide curfew is in effect from 5:00pm until 4:00am. Those in violation of the curfew order will be imprisoned for up to three years and fined 10,000 KD. Foreign nationals found in violation of the curfew order also risk deportation.
On April 20, 2020 Kuwait government decided to the extend partial curfew for 16 hours. From the first day of Ramadan, the curfew would start at 4:00 p.m. until 8:00 a.m. the next day.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Since March 22, 2020, Kuwait has implemented a nationwide curfew is in effect from 5:00pm until 4:00am. Those in violation of the curfew order will be imprisoned for up to three years and fined 10,000 KD. Foreign nationals found in violation of the curfew order also risk deportation.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Kuwait has extended its partial curfew by two hours in the morning to run from 5 p.m. until 6 a.m. starting from April 6, 2020 until further notice. The government has also encouraged citizens to remain indoors during non-curfew hours.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Kuwait has extended its partial curfew by two hours in the morning to run from 5 p.m. until 6 a.m. starting from April 6, 2020 until further notice. The government has also encouraged citizens to remain indoors during non-curfew hours.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On May 28, 2020 it was announced that Kuwait will enforce a 12-hour partial curfew from 6pm to 6am starting May 31 as part of a five-phase plan to gradually return to normal life.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
On May 28, 2020 it was announced that Kuwait will enforce a 12-hour partial curfew from 6pm to 6am starting May 31 as part of a five-phase plan to gradually return to normal life.
On June 25, 2020, Kuwait has decided to start the second phase to return to normal life by easing curfew hours to start at 8pm and end 5am starting from June 30. This is change to the previous curfew timings in place.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: On February 24, 2020, Kuwait suspended all outbound and inbound flights from Italy, South Korea and Thailand. No entry visas will be issued to travelers from these three countries.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of March 11, 2020, non-Kuwaiti citizens are barred from entering Kuwait through the airport. This does not apply to first degree relatives who are traveling with their Kuwaiti family member. The Kuwait Cabinet has also authorised the Ministry of Interior to suspend granting of all types of visas except for those used by diplomatic delegations.

On March 11, 2020, the government of Kuwait announced that all inbound and outbound commercial flights would be suspended starting from March 13. The Kuwait International Airport will be closed indefinitely. Entry will only be allowed to Kuwaiti nationals and first-degree relatives. Cargo traffic continues.

According to Kuwait's Ministerial Decision 288 dated March 26, 2020,    foreign nationals who do not have a residence permit or whose residency has expired have the option to depart Kuwait between April 1 and April 30, 2020 without paying a fine.
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description:
On April 15, 2020, Kuwait's Ministry of Interior announced that if a foreign national’s tourist visa or residency expired or will expire between March 1 and May 30, it will automatically be extended until May 31, 2020.
On May 23, 2020 it was reported that expats whose visas will expire by the end of May will be given a three-month free extension, from June 1 until August 31. The extension will only apply to individuals whose visas will expire by end of May and are still in Kuwait. Visa sponsors can apply online via the ministry’s website.
type_text: This policy involves automatically extending tourist visas or residency visas for foreign nationals that have expired within a given period.
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description: As of May 30, 2020, The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) of Kuwait has decided that Kuwaiti nationals, their first-degree relatives, as well as accompanying nannies and house workers will be allowed to book flights back to the country. This measure came after the end of the repatriation plan sponsored by the government for Kuwaitis abroad. Airliners and carriers were notified and will be allowing flight booking for Kuwaitis abroad.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Kuwaiti Minister of Oil, Acting Minister of Electricity and Water announced on June 10, 2020 the stoppage of employing expatriates in the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation (KPC) and its subsidiaries.The Minister of Oil, addressing a parliamentary committee session, said the non-Kuwaitis would not be hired in the KPC and its subsidiary for the year 2020- 2021 and their numbers as to special contracts would be trimmed. Kuwaiti citizens serving in the national petroleum companies would also potentially be laid off.
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of March 22 2020 Kuwait has announced that all private medical offices clinics and laboratories are closed until further notice Public and private hospitals and private hospital clinics remain openStarting April 22 2020 the Ministry of Health has allowed private medical clinics to reopen for three days a week from 1100am to 200pm Appointments at dental clinics are available for emergencies only

On May 16, 2020, Kuwait’s Ministry of Health announced that it has opened a drive-through coronavirus testing centre at Jazeera Airways’ park and fly facility at Kuwait International Airport. The centre, which can receive 15 cars at any one time, will be used to carry out 180 tests a day for people from the six governorates. The ministry is to work with the Public Authority for the Civil Information to randomly nominate 180 people, representing the different state areas, both males and females, and different age categories, for the tests. SMS will be sent to the phones of the selected people, which will include all related information about the date, time and location of the testing.

On May 21, 2020, Kuwait announced that its medical team has developed a Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) solution to used for coronavirus tests. The new solution developed by the Kuwaiti specialists has ‘excellent’ diagnostic results, Dr. Salman Al-Sabah, head of the surgical department at Jaber Al-Ahmad Hospital, said. PCR testing is considered a more accurate method of diagnosing the presence of coronavirus among patients according to WHO where a swab is taken and blended with a reagent usually called a PCR Kit, of which a solution the Kuwaiti medical team has developed. The team is now in the initial stages of the solution’s production before output is ramped up on a bigger scale to satisfy local requirements and reduce dependence on imported reagents that are costlier and take a longer delivery period.

On May 26, 2020, the Kuwaiti government announced decisions related to quarantine facilities and improving the accommodation of workers. The halls in the Tadhamon Sport Club will be transformed into a field emergency unit to support Farwaniya Hospital. All companies are asked to provide housing units for infected workers. Hotels are also to be leased to use as quarantine facilities.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 18, 2020, Kuwait's Health Ministry reported that it intends to approve the use of dexamethasone in its protocol treating the new coronavirus. The anti-inflammation medication will be used in Kuwait after related recommendations from the World Health Organisation (WHO).
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of March 13, 2020, all public transportation, including taxi services, is suspended in Kuwait.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Kuwait, the government announced a full lockdown on two densely-populated districts starting from April 6, 2020. The two districts to be put under a two-week “complete isolation” are Jleeb al-Shuyoukh and Mahboula, two heavily populated areas where expatriate workers live.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: In Kuwait, the government announced a full lockdown on two densely-populated districts starting from April 6, 2020. The two districts to be put under a two-week “complete isolation” are Jleeb al-Shuyoukh and Mahboula, two heavily populated areas where expatriate workers live. This lockdown has been extended in duration indefinitely and is extended to other areas of Farwaniya, Khaitan, Hawally, Nuqra and Maidan Hawally from May 28, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: On May 8, 2020, Kuwait has announced a “total” lockdown of 20 days to combat the coronavirus pandemic. It will begin at 4pm on May 10, 2020 and continue until May 30, 2020. Public sector will continue to work remotely and all but essential private sector activities will be suspended. Essential sectors such as health, security, electricity, oil and municipal services, as well as private sector companies providing services like maintenance, will be exempt from the lockdown. The workers in these sectors will be given permits. Supermarkets and food outlets will remain open, but those wishing to visit them will have to obtain a permit to do so. Only one person from each family will be allowed out for shopping. People will be required to wear protective masks and practice social distancing when out of their homes and are allowed to go out for walks between 4.30pm and 6.30pm, without using any vehicles. Home deliveries will be allowed only for essential food and pharmaceutical supplies.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On May 8, 2020, Kuwait has announced a “total” lockdown of 20 days to combat the coronavirus pandemic. It will begin at 4pm on May 10, 2020 and continue until May 30, 2020. Public sector will continue to work remotely and all but essential private sector activities will be suspended. Essential sectors such as health, security, electricity, oil and municipal services, as well as private sector companies providing services like maintenance, will be exempt from the lockdown. The workers in these sectors will be given permits. Supermarkets and food outlets will remain open, but those wishing to visit them will have to obtain a permit to do so. Only one person from each family will be allowed out for shopping. People will be required to wear protective masks and practice social distancing when out of their homes and are allowed to go out for walks between 4.30pm and 6.30pm, without using any vehicles. Home deliveries will be allowed only for essential food and pharmaceutical supplies. 
On May 25, 2020, it was announced that after May 30, Kuwait will replace the complete lockdown with a partial curfew in effect from May 31, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: As of May 16, 2020, the working hours of grocery shops in Kuwait will be changed during the lockdown period until May 30. The grocery stores in investment areas are permitted to deliver food and other items to nearby residents from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Grocery stores are required to stop using vehicles in the home delivery service, and to stop shoppers from entering their stores.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
On March 11, 2020, the Kuwaiti government announced a ""public holiday"" which will take effect from March 12 to March 26. This involves temporary suspension of educational institutions, government offices, commercial businesses such as shopping malls, theme parks and salons along with congressional prayers. 
It was extended to last until April 26, 2020 as precautionary measures against the coronavirus.
As of April 20, 2020, Kuwait has extended its national public holiday until May 28, 2020.
type_text: This a nation-wide public holiday where businesses and government offices remain closed.

description: Kuwait has extended its public holiday by two weeks until April 26, 2020 as precautionary measures against the coronavirus.
type_text: Kuwait has declared a nation-wide public holiday. This involves suspension of educational institutions, government offices, commercial businesses such as shopping malls, theme parks and salons along with congressional prayers.

description: As of 29th May 2020, the Kuwait Government decided to extend holiday of public sector until further notice.
type_text: Kuwait has declared a nation-wide public holiday. This involves suspension of educational institutions, government offices, commercial businesses such as shopping malls, theme parks and salons along with congressional prayers.

description:
On April 15, 2020, Kuwait's Ministry of Interior announced that if a foreign national’s tourist visa or residency expired or will expire between March 1 and May 30, it will automatically be extended until May 31, 2020.

On May 23, 2020 it was reported that expats whose visas will expire by the end of May will be given a three-month free extension, from June 1 until August 31.The extension will only apply to individuals whose visas will expire by end of May and are still in Kuwait. Visa sponsors can apply online via the ministry’s website.
type_text: This policy involves automatically extending tourist visas or residency visas for foreign nationals that have expired within a given period.
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)

description:
It was announced on April 13 that the grand repatriation plan for Kuwaiti nationals abroad will begin on April 19, 2020 and will last for 19 days.
Repatriated Kuwaitis would be divided into three groups. The first batch will include those who need mobile beds and life support equipment.
All returning citizens would be subject to standard medical procedures  such as measuring temperature and conducting swab tests, before determining if they should institutionalize or move to house quarantines. Further details are provided on each step of the grand repatriation plan in the press release by KUNA (Kuwait News Agency).
type_text: Kuwait had decided to implement a grand repatriation plan that involves bringing back citizens of Kuwait who are living abroad.

description:
It was announced on April 13 that the grand repatriation plan for Kuwaiti nationals abroad will begin on April 19, 2020 and will last for 19 days.
Repatriated Kuwaitis would be divided into three groups. The first batch will include those who need mobile beds and life support equipment.
All returning citizens would be subject to standard medical procedures  such as measuring temperature and conducting swab tests, before determining if they should institutionalize or move to house quarantines. Further details are provided on each step of the grand repatriation plan in the press release by KUNA (Kuwait News Agency).
type_text: Kuwait had decided to implement a grand repatriation plan that involves bringing back citizens of Kuwait who are living abroad.

description: On May 23, 2020, Kuwait has stated that it will allow residency renewal for diplomatic staff and representatives of state bodies through the Ministry of Interior’s website moi.gov.kw. The step comes as part of the country’s efforts to develop security services, enabling people to save time and have their residencies renewed in a more efficient manner, the ministry said in a statement. State bodies and diplomatic missions were also asked to list the names and contact details of their representatives responsible for renewing the residencies of their staff members.
type_text: This policy involves facilitating visa renewal for diplomatic staff amidst the covid crisis.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 26, 2020, it was announced that Kuwait has set up a toll-free hotline to provide psychological consultation to distressed citizens and residents as the country tackles coronavirus. Members of the Kuwait Psychological Association (KPA) are helping out with this process and experts will also reach out to citizens and residents who are in quarantine either at home or at health facilities to provide them with psychological support.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of March 24, 2020, Kuwaiti citizens and residents who enter Kuwait from any country will be put in institutional quarantine for at least 14 days upon arrival.

On May 25, 2020 Kuwait announced that its Ministry of Health has adopted a new mechanism for dealing with medical staff infected with covid-19. If someone from medical teams contracts the virus, he or she will be home-quarantined and then be tested on the fifth day of infection. In case of negative tests, he or she will be allowed to get back to work, provided personal protection kits are used. Confirmed positive cases will be placed under home quarantine and then be tested on the 12th or 13th day, and in case of negative tests, they will be able to return to work on the 14th day.
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 11, 2020, the Kuwaiti government announced a ""public holiday"" which will take effect from March 12 to March 26. This involves temporary suspension of educational institutions, government offices, commercial businesses such as shopping malls, theme parks and salons along with congressional prayers.

On March 11, 2020, the Kuwaiti government announced a ""public holiday"" which will take effect from March 12 to March 26. This involves temporary suspension of educational institutions, government offices, commercial businesses such as shopping malls, theme parks and salons along with congressional prayers. 
On April 20, 2020, the nation-wide public holiday was extended until May 28, 2020.
type_text: Kuwait has declared a nation-wide public holiday. This involves suspension of educational institutions, government offices, commercial businesses such as shopping malls, theme parks and salons along with congressional prayers.

description: On April 2, 2020, the Kuwait cabinet has announced the closure of all car maintenance and spare parts shops along with the reduction of workers at consumer cooperative societies to help curb the spread of COVID-19.

Starting from May 31, 2020, Kuwait has announced that parallel markets will be able to operate between 6:00 am to 5:30 pm local-time prior to the partial curfew in the Kuwaiti Municipality. The partial curfew is from 6:00 pm until 6:00 am.

On June 25, 2020 it was announced that employees in the private sector will resume work with less than 30 percent capacity starting from June 30. This is part of the second phase of resuming life back to normal in Kuwait and it will last for a period of three weeks. This policy includes reopening of shopping malls, the financial sector, construction sector, retail shops, parks, and takeaway from restaurants and cafes.

It was announced on June 1, 2020 that the Kuwait National Assembly will resume regular sessions on June 16 to discuss government's measures against coronavirus. This marks an end of the nation-wide public holiday in the government sector as parliament resumes its duties.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: As of March 13, 2020, the Kuwaiti government has closed all mosques, public parks, beaches, and public spaces are closed until further notice. Many types of social gatherings, including weddings, receptions, and public and private diwaniyas, are banned.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event

description:
As of March 13, 2020, the Kuwaiti government has closed all mosques, public parks, beaches, and public spaces are closed until further notice. Many types of social gatherings, including weddings, receptions, and public and private diwaniyas, are banned.
As of June 10, 2020, mosques are allowed to open in some residential areas as part of the first phase of the plan to gradually return citizens to normal life.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event

description: On June 7, 2020, the Ministry of Awqaf and Islamic Affairs stated that it had given the green light to mosques, in some areas, after almost three months of closure due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. These include mosques in the model residential areas, sparsely-populated areas, which will receive worshipers for the five daily prayers starting of noon prayer of June 10, 2020 while all abide by the preventive and precautionary measures outlined by the state's health authorities. The weekly Friday noon sermon and prayer will be performed only at the Grand Mosque in Kuwait City and will be broadcast on the official Kuwait TV. Only the mosque's preacher and staff will be allowed to attend this prayer.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 18, 2020, Kuwait has warned its people that failing wear protective face masks will be punishable by up to 3 months in jail and a maximum of 5,000 dinars in fines.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
